title: 110_hr589
content: The "Get Real Incentives to Drive Plug-in Act" defines a plug-in hybrid electric vehicle as a vehicle using combustible fuel, rechargeable storage, and off-board electricity. The Act authorizes research grants for domestic motor vehicle facilities to develop plug-in hybrids, with $500,000,000 allocated for fiscal years 2008-2012. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a pilot project to integrate plug-in hybrid electric vehicles into the electric power grid and transportation infrastructure. A test site for battery technology advancement will be created, modeled after the NHTSA Vehicle Research and Test Center in Ohio. Within 2 years of the Act's enactment, a plan for plug-in hybrid electric vehicle support infrastructure will be submitted to Congress. Additionally, a tax credit for plug-in hybrid motor vehicles will be implemented. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new plug-in hybrid motor vehicle credit of $3,000 for new qualified plug-in hybrid motor vehicles with a gross vehicle weight rating of not more than 8,500 pounds. A hybrid motor vehicle is defined as a vehicle propelled by an internal combustion engine using combustible fuel, an on-board rechargeable storage device, and a means of using off-board electricity. It must also meet or exceed the Bin 5 Tier II emission level for passenger automobiles or light trucks. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new plug-in hybrid motor vehicle credit for taxpayers who acquire a new qualified plug-in hybrid vehicle for personal use. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after the date of the enactment of this Act, in taxable years ending after such date. SEC. 8. REQUIREMENT REGARDING PURCHASE OF MOTOR VEHICLES BY EXECUTIVE AGENCIES. Executive agencies must purchase at least 10 percent plug-in hybrid electric vehicles in any fiscal year. Definitions include Executive agency, motor vehicle, and pro-rated applicability in the year of enactment.
